Um...
Thanks for this! These stories either slipped my mind completely or I simply wasn't paying attention.

I've looked them up right on their website. There used to be one woman who seems to be of South Asian ancestry, but she's no longer reading for them.
And I'm not sure if they're volunteers or if they're paid (I would imagine they get compensation now due to the shows success), but I think that's irrelevant to my question.
I've heard David make an announcement at the beginning of a show that they get lots of interest from people wanting to read for them but that they aren't looking for new voice actors. I find it hard to believe that zero people of color have reached out with interest in joining their ranks. So if they have discovered their actors solely through a voluntary process, the basis for your response simply doesn't make sense.
As a mixed-black queer woman, I'm fully aware that there's no such thing as "sounding" a race, ethnicity, sexual preference, or even a gender/sex etc. But it would be cool to hear some accents that aren't white British or white Irish or white Canadian or white American. It would be cool to hear African accents, Asian Accents. It would even be cool to hear stories read by black and brown American folx with certain vernaculars that some might say are stereotypical as people who use certain vernaculars do exist and as a person who grew up in and around it, the "hood" has some scary happenings/stories. It would be cool to hear an extremely effeminate male voice actor read for them. It would be cool to hear a gender-ambiguous voice. It would be cool to hear stories by and about POC and LGBTQIA folx and the things that only we experience.
And for every one listener that would stop listening due to their inability to relate to anything that isn't white and hetero, I know the show would gain two more listeners who would be stoked on the representation.
I also want to note that I don't think anyone who controls anything on the show is at all racist or intentionally excluding anyone, but I do think they simply aren't fully cognizant of how important representation is, especially when you're getting as big as NoSleep is getting.

I'm not really offended, per say. Just curious is all.
If Eurocentricity and heteronormativity offended me, I would spend my life in a state of offense. I like the straights and the whites! Many of friends and family members are straight and white. I adore the voice actor roster and the stories NoSleep picks. It would just be cool to have some variation.
And I actually just wrote my first story. As my writing gets better, I plan to submit directly to the podcast.

WRITING.TITLE: Los Bastardos: Bastard #1
WRITING.TEXT:
You have to believe me when I tell you that I never meant to murder anyone. But he kept trying to put is filthy hands up my shirt! I repeatedly told the bastard "NO!" Like so many before him, he persisted. As I sat there nearly giving up my protest out of fear that, if I didn't, the situation might quickly turn more violent and deadly dangerous... it was as if every hurt, every bruise, every assault, every ignored "no," every removal of rights and autonomy and agency ever inflicted on any woman suddenly became my own.
I could feel the rage in my being reaching critical mass and something inside me broke wide open.
As bastard #1 roughly pawed at my breasts and drunkenly drooled all over my neck, I felt around in my nightstand for the Montblanc Bonheur Fountain Pen my aunt had gifted to me last Eid. I'm quite sure he thought I was searching for a condom for his undoubtedly minuscule dick. "Got it!" I thought to myself as I gently removed the pen's cap. Then, with all the force I could muster from my 5'2" frame, I jabbed the Montblanc directly into what I hoped was his jugular. I pushed it in deep, twisted it around a bit, and swiftly pulled it back out. If the massive spurts of blood emitting from his neck were any indication, I had successfully found that precious vein.
He looked at me with wide-eyed puzzlement, I stared directly back at him with wide-smile amusement.
"You stabbed me, you stupid bitch!" were his last words before collapsing. I watched as he continued to bleed, slower now, onto my floor. I listened to his breaths becoming fainter and fainter. I headed to the kitchen to borrow my carnivorous roommate's meat cleaver and returned to my room, where he was lying on the floor, unfortunately still gasping for oxygen.
I stood over him, stared at him, then sat down on his chest with the meat cleaver in my right hand. With my left, I poked and prodded and stuck my fingers into the gaping hole I made just ten minutes before.
I took stock of the situation in which I found myself and began slicing into the flesh and bones of his neck until his head was completely detached from his pathetic body. His eyes were still wide open and his face still bore the signs of sheer terror.
Sitting atop his lifeless (and now headless) body, I never felt more invigorated. And the release of the kill was absolutely magnificent, I tell you! Every fear, every hurt... all things fell away. I held the power.
I was almost giddy with euphoria until I realized I still had work to do on behalf of bastard #1's mistakes. Ugh. Even in death, men are writhing disappoints. I mean, he didn't even have the decency to bleed out on a blanket or something. Nope, right onto my gleaming, pristine pre-war hardwood. The bastard.
"You've made such a fucking mess!" I shouted at his corpse as I set about cleaning up after him.
The Jerk, Baby Boy, Mean Girls

WRITING.TITLE: I want to leave
WRITING.TEXT:
I've only been Muslim for 1.5 years and have only been married for 6 months, but I am miserable. My husband is a wonderful man. He's sweet, gentle, and understanding. But he would never leave Islam. He's happy in it. It's been his way of life for 20 years, since he was just 15. For me, it is oppressive and constricting and bleak. It feels akin to nihilism and I absolutely cannot stand it. I do not know why I even took my shahada. Now, I'm in the KSA and trying to figure out how to leave without hurting my husband. I don't want to break his heart, but I am so unhappy.

WRITING.TITLE: Pisces connection of some sort?
WRITING.TEXT:
I know others have pointed out all of the fish/fishing references, but I haven't seen mention of the many uses of water as a theme, as well as feet. This might be a stretch, but the astrological sign Pisces symbol/constellation is two fish swimming in opposite directions, it is a water sign, the body part ruled by Pisces are the feet, and the word Pisces itself is the plural for fish in Latin. This could mean nothing, but wondering if anyone else noticed these things?
Also, I'm rewatching the series now and I noticed in episode one, the nurse tells The OA that she has hypothermia. Further along in the series, Hap also mentions that The OA was almost hypothermic after she's been in his ND contraption. Any theories about these references?
Also, I cannot recall a series that has ever moved me the way The OA has, like ever.

Salamulaykum Wa Rahmatullahi Wa Barakatuh.
Plucking the eyebrows is not permissible in Islam. It is called Al Namas.
Abd-Allaah ibn Masood (radi Allah Tala Anhu) said: "I heard the Messenger of Allaah (Sallallahu Alayhi Wasallam) say: Allaah has cursed the woman who does tattoos and the one who has them done, the woman who plucks eyebrows (al-naamisah) and the one who has it done (al-mutanammisah), and the one who files her teeth for the purpose of beauty, altering the creation of Allaah.
(al-Bukhaari, 5931; Muslim, 2125)
However, in Fatwa al-Lajnah al-Daaimah, it is stated:
There is no sin on a woman if she removes hair on her upper lip, thighs, calves and arms. This is not part of the tanammus (plucking) that is forbidden.
(Fatwa al-Lajnah al-Daaimah, 5/194, 195)
The Committee was asked:
What is the Islamic ruling on plucking the hair between the eyebrows?
They replied:
It is permissible to pluck it, because it is not part of the eyebrows.
(Fatwa al-Lajnah al-Daaimah, 5/197)
Of course, Allah knows best, but I hope this helps!

Agreed. In our Deen, Allah SWT isn't male or female. Allah is not human and Allah's human creations do not resemble Him other than having attributes like Him. That is, eyes with which to see and ears with which to hear, etc. But in Islam, we don't believe Allah is some human looking male with a big, white beard looking over us. That is an egotistical and patriarchal Christian way of thought, of which we do not subscribe to.
Allah is infinite and Allah created everything; time, space, heaven, earth, male, female, jinn, animals, sun, moon, stars, etc. Therefore, he could never be likened to humans. Human beings are finite, and Allah is beyond our comprehension.
